attributes.title: Instagram - A Priming Study
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
Instagram Priming (orthogonal, within-participant)
-positive priming
-negative priming
-no priming at all

question2b.value:
Social capital
State self-esteem
satisafaction with life

question3b.value: social capital (just for hypothesis 3 and 4 as a mediator variable)

question10b.value:
An online experiment via the platform Qualtrics will be constructed and the collection of the data will take place from the mid of February until the 31th of March. The use of an online questionnaire has the advantage that it is anonym and time- and location-independent (Döring, 2003). Participants will be recruited using a snowball sampling technique through campus-wide emails, flyers, posting a link online on social media sites (Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram) and using the platform “Survey Circle”. The final sample should consist (as calculated with the program G*Power 3.1) of at least 252 participants, so that 84 participants are in each group. The statistical analysis will be done with the statistics program SPSS (Ibm, 2017).
The study will have two different priming conditions (positive Instagram priming vs. negative Instagram priming) and one control condition in which no priming occurs in the questionnaire. After some information about the survey and the letter of agreement, which the participants will have to agree, the participants will answer some demographic items (e.g. sex, age, nationality, specific questions about Instagram and highest educational degree). After the demographics the participants will complete a questionnaire specific for their Instagram use. The next part is the priming paradigm which is based on former priming studies showing that priming with SNS has an influence on perceived social capital (Chiou et al., 2015) and self-esteem (Gonzales & Hancock, 2011) which might also affect satisfaction with life. The priming paradigm is the independent variable. 
The participants will be randomly assigned to three different priming conditions: positive Instagram priming, negative Instagram priming and no priming at all. In the two priming conditions, the participants will read a story about Instagram and imagine that they are the person in the story. At the beginning of the stories the person has a good day with friends and posts a picture of himself/ herself on Instagram in the evening. In the positive priming condition, the person gets a lot of likes and positive comments as feedback to the post. In the negative priming condition, the person does not get many likes and negative comments as feedback to the post. After the positive or negative feedback, the story ends up and the participants will be asked some questions about their feelings (“How do you feel after such comments?”, “How do you react after such comments?” and “What do you think about your followers now?”).
In the no priming condition, the participants will just have to complete all the questionnaires and will not read any story about Instagram. 
Furthermore, the participants will fill out questionnaires about self-esteem, satisfaction with life and social capital which serve as the dependent variables. Right after the priming one item of each scale will occur, which has the highest factor loading, because priming effects pass by fast (Förster & Liberman, 2007; Förster, Liberman, & Friedman, 2007). All other measures (except for the Instagram questionnaire which shows up at the beginning) will be presented completely randomized, so that no order effects can occur. At the end of the study the participants will have to answer some last three control questions about the story they have just read (if they were in one of the priming conditions) to make sure that they really have paid attention to the story.

question1a.value:
1.	Social capital is positively correlated with satisfaction with life and self-esteem.
2.	Self-esteem is positively correlated with satisfaction with life.
3.	Perceived social capital mediates the association between Instagram use and self-esteem.
4.	Perceived social capital mediates the association between Instagram use and satisfaction with life.
5.	Positive feedback on Instagram leads to more perceived social capital than negative feedback or no feedback.
6.	Positive feedback on Instagram leads to more satisfaction with life than negative feedback or no feedback.
7.	Positive feedback on Instagram leads to higher self-esteem than negative feedback or no feedback.

attributes.title: Cognitive bias modification for interpretations
attributes.description: An investigation into the underlying cognitive mechanisms of worry

q1.value: Cognitive bias modification for interpretations: an investigation into the underlying cognitive mechanisms of worry

q3.value: The aim of the proposed study is to explore the underlying cognitive mechanisms of worry. In particular, we aim to assess whether interpretations can be modified outside of conscious awareness. A training paradigm will be used to subliminally present positive resolutions to ambiguous scenarios, to see whether a training effect occurs.

q4.value: It is hypothesised that subliminally training positive resolutions to ambiguous materials (compared to a control condition that will involve subliminally presenting neutral resolutions unrelated to the ambiguity) will promote a more positive interpretation bias and reduce levels of state worry and anxiety.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Experimental design using quantitative methodology and inferential statistics. One experimental session will be used to train – for the first time – a more positive interpretation bias where resolutions are presented subliminally. There will be two groups: experimental (‘positively trained’) or control condition (‘sham trained’ – an inactive training condition). The independent variable is the allocated training condition and the dependent variables are measures of IB and measures of state worry and anxiety.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to either an experimental or control condition using the appropriate web application (TBC).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the community via advertisements online (i.e., Twitter), as well as via the University of Liverpool circular emails. Information about participation (i.e., informed consent) and the nature of the research will be accessible online via Qualtrics. Those who take part in the study will be paid £10 for their participation and offered compensation for reasonable travel expenses.

q14.value: A power analysis was conducted using G*Power software (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007), which indicated that a sample of at least 50 participants would be required for the study to achieve 80% power at p=0.05 to reveal a medium effect size.

question.value:
There will be two groups: experimental (‘positively trained’) or control condition (‘sham trained’ – an inactive training condition). The independent variable is the allocated training condition.

Computerised interpretation training/control task:
•	The Word Sentence Association Paradigm (WSAP)

Screening measure
•	The Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ) 

Measures of interpretation bias (near transfer)
•	The scrambled sentences task (SST) 
•	The recognition test (RT) 

Measure of state worry and anxiety (far transfer)
•	‘Breathing focus task’ to measure state worry
•	The State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-State)

Descriptive statistics will be used to assess demographic information, in order to ensure that random assignment does not create group differences. Inferential statistical analyses will be carried out using Stata 16 software (StataCorp, 2019). Two-factor (training condition x time pre/post) mixed ANOVAS will be used to examine the effect of the interpretation training on measures of IB and measures of state worry and anxiety.

attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of sacubitril/valsartan in the treatment of heart failure: protocol for a systematic review incorporating unpublished clinical study reports
Effects and Mechanisms of Chinese Herbal Medicine for Ulcerative Colitis in: Protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effects and Mechanisms of Chinese Herbal Medicine for Ulcerative Colitis in: Protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Qiaobo Ye, ZhipengHu, MaoyiYang, Kaihua Qin, Yingguang Zhou

q3.value: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) is a common intestinal disease. Its clinical manifestations are abdominal pain, diarrhea, mucopurulent and bloody stool, urgency and heaviness. More and more studies have confirmed that Chinese herbal medicine has a good effect on UC and the mechanism is the combination of multiple targets. However, there is no systematic review and meta-analysis to collate and evaluate the evidence of these animal studies. The purpose of this study is to provide direct evidence of the efficacy and mechanism of Chinese herbal medicine in treating UC.

q4.value: If Chinese herbal medicine is effective for ulcerative colitis, the pathology of ulcerative colitis will be improved

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will search seven databases, including three English databases and four Chinese databases. In addition, other animal research sources should also be searched. According to the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the two researchers independently selected eligible documents by reading titles, abstracts and full texts. Then, other researchers completed the bias risk assessment and data extraction, and conducted a meta-analysis of the results. The outcome indicators include disease activity index, IL-1β, IL-4, IL-6, IL-17; colombosa damage index, CMDI; MPO; EGF; TGF -β1 and histopathological score. We used Cochrane X2 and I2 tests to complete the data heterogeneity analysis. We completed subgroup analysis according to duration, administration method (oral, enema, traditional Chinese medicine fumigation), modeling method (TNBS, DSS), animal category (rats or mice). We will also evaluate the stability of the results through sensitivity analysis; evaluate publishing deviation through funnel chart analysis and egger test; and evaluate the quality of evidence through Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluate system.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will search seven databases, including three English databases and four Chinese databases. In addition, other animal research sources should also be searched. According to the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the two researchers independently selected eligible documents by reading titles, abstracts and full texts.

q13.value: We will search seven databases, including three English databases and four Chinese databases. In addition, other animal research sources should also be searched. All studies that meet the requirements are included.

question.value: The outcome indicators include disease activity index, IL-1β, IL-4, IL-6, IL-17; colombosa damage index, CMDI; MPO; EGF; TGF -β1 and histopathological score.

We used Cochrane X2 and I2 tests to complete the data heterogeneity analysis. We completed subgroup analysis according to duration, administration method (oral, enema, traditional Chinese medicine fumigation), modeling method (TNBS, DSS), animal category (rats or mice). We will also evaluate the stability of the results through sensitivity analysis; evaluate publishing deviation through funnel chart analysis and egger test; and evaluate the quality of evidence through Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluate system.

attributes.title: A fMRI study on brain change during poem learning

q1.value: Brain changes after learning to memorize and comprehend poems

q3.value: In this study, we will examine the brain changes after a 15-days self-learning program to memorize and comprehend ancient Chinese poems measured by functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI). Brain activity will be collected during listening to poem recitation and viewing concurrent subtitle presentation before and after their learning programs. Participants will be arbitrarily assigned to one version of learning protocol, aiming for either recognition or comprehension. The main purpose of this study is to 1) identify brain regions and functional networks recruited in the recognition and comprehension of ancient Chinese poems, 2) explore how the activation of literacy-related areas (such as VWFA and PT) changes after ancient Chinese poem learning, 3) investigate how learning-induced brain changes are associated with behavioral performance.

q4.value:
Aim 1: Identify brain regions recruited in the recognition and comprehension of ancient Chinese poems.
Brain activity collected using Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) during viewing poem recitation videos before and after leaning will be used to identify brain regions and functional networks recruited in the recognition and comprehension of the poems. The identification process follows from postulates: With the same audiovisual sensory inputs, extensive brain regions and functional networks related to cognitive processing such as attention, long-term memory and language, will be recruited after learning to recognize or comprehend poems. Besides, we predict multimodal sensory integration and sensory-motor interaction will be present after learning for recognition, while frontal-temporal activity involving deeper-level semantic processing will be present after learning for comprehension.

Aim 2: Explore how the activation of literacy-related areas (such as VWFA and PT) changes after ancient Chinese poem learning.
We predict that the activity in literacy-related areas, such as Visual Word Form Area (VWFA) and Planum Temporale (PT), will be modulated by learning experience and learning protocols. 

Aim 3: Investigate how learning-induced brain changes are related to behavioral performance.
If the brain regions and functional networks identified in the efforts aiming towards Aim 1 and 2 are critical for the poem learning, the brain activity changes will be associated with behavioral performance in the final exam after the learning program.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Design type (task, rest; event-related, block)	
      Task fMRI, block design

Conditions & Stimuli 
Between subject variables:  
•	Learning protocols (recognition group versus comprehension group)
Within subject variables: 
•	Poem type (learnt versus unlearnt)
•	Learning (Pre- versus post-learning)

Between subject variables:  
•	Learning protocols (recognition group versus comprehension group)
Within subject variables: 
•	Poem type (learnt versus unlearnt)
•	Learning (Pre- versus post-learning)
Stimuli:
•	Experimental stimuli for fMRI:
       Twenty-four poems from the Book of Songs are selected for the experiment. Concurrent subtitles are added to the audio recitations to produce videos for each poem (one character by one character popping out at the center of screen). The audio recitations from the same reader are downloaded from the Internet and accompanied with background music. Each poem is cut into 3 epochs (16-seconds long), making 72 epochs in total. During the fMRI presentation, one character in the subtitle may increase the font size or not.
•	Localizer stimuli for fMRI study
       Twelve Chinese characters, their corresponding scrambled images and twelve face images will be used for the localizer task in fMRI.  
•	Learning materials
       Only half the poems will be recruited in the learning process, leaving the other half as controls. We try to balance between the learnt poems and the controls with respective to the background music and theme of the poems for fMRI study. Only poem scripts will be offered to the participants during the learning process.

Number of blocks, trials or experimental units per session and/or subject	
      There are 1 localizer run and 6 experimental runs, with 12 blocks per experimental run. Each participant completes two sessions, one for pre-learning and the other for post-learning.

Timing and Duration (length of each trial and interval between trials)	
      Each experimental block is an epoch of poem video, which lasts for 16 seconds. The resting intervals between poem epochs are also 16 seconds. During the localizer task, each block lasts for 12 seconds. Each block consists 12 trials, which lasts for 500 milliseconds. The
intervals between trials are 500 milliseconds.

Length of experiment (length of full scan and each run)	
      The whole fMRI experiment consists two sessions. Each session takes about 1 hour (10 mins for anatomical imaging, 8 mins for localizer and 42 mins for experimental runs)

Was the design optimized for efficiency, and if so, how?	
      N/A

Presentation software (name, version, operating system; code if possible)
      Matlab with psychotoolbox.

Task Specification 
Instructions to subjects (what were they asked to do?) 	
-	Learning protocol
-	Fmri experiment

Stimuli (what were they; how many were there; did it repeat across trials?)	
•	Experimental stimuli for fMRI:
      Twenty-four poems from the Book of Songs are selected for the experiment. Concurrent subtitles are added to the audio recitations to produce videos for each poem (one character by one character popping out at the center of screen). The audio recitations from the same reader are downloaded from the Internet and accompanied with background music. Each poem is cut into 3 epochs (16-seconds long), making 72 epochs in total. During the fMRI presentation, one character in the subtitle may increase the font size or not.

Stimuli presentation & response collection 	
      Audiovisual stimuli will be presented with MRI-compatible screen and headphones. Responses will be collected using handstick with buttons.

Randomization/pseudo-randomized (why/why not done & how)	
      The sequence of learnt/unlearnt poem epochs during the experimental runs will be pseudo-randomized, to interleave learnt and unlearnt poems but avoid two consecutive epochs from one single poem.  

Run order (of tasks within scanner)	
Anatomical imaging- three experimental runs – one localizer run - three experimental runs

-This study will have two groups ,each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two group. “A” group need to copy the poem ten times everyday during the learning process. “B” group need to collect some information about the poem such as the phonetic transcription and the meaning of some words.
-The materials of fMRI experiment will be randomly selected from ShiJing(24 ancient poems). Each poem will be seperated into 3 parts and made into videos.
-Every video has been changed one Chinese word’s size and we randomly choose thirty-six of these changed videos and thirty-six unchanged videos as the materials of main experiments in a random order.

question.value:
-Population
	University students in Canton, China
-Recruitment efforts
	Volunteer assignment from Internet.
-Inclusion/Exclusion criteria
	In order to avoid complicated influence from specific educational background, Students with a major in Chinese Language & Literature will be not applicable to assign for the study.
-Clinical criteria (if applicable)
	N/A
-Matching strategy (if applicable)
	Participants will be arbitrarily assigned to two learning protocols, with sex matched between groups.
-Payment for participation
	Cash payment (350 RMB)
-IRB, consent/assent obtained
	Yes, we have obtained IRB for both behavioral and fMRI study from ethical committee of South China Normal University. Hand-written consent forms from each participants will be collected prior to the study. 
-Number of subjects participated and analyzed
	We intend to collect at least 40 participants (Up to now 10 collected but not analyzed yet)
-Age
	N/A
-Sex
	N/A
-Handedness
	N/A
-For group comparisons, what variables (if any) were equated across groups?
	We intend to try to balance age and sex between two learning protocol groups during group assignment.
-Study timeline (e.g., number of visits, length of visits, what was measured/collected at each visit)
	Three visits in total. The first visit is to our behavioral laboratory to do Poem Knowledge Level test, inform the details of the learning protocol and sign paperwork. The second and third visit is to the MRI center for a 1-hour scan for each time, with an interval of 15 days for poem learning. A final behavioral test about the learnt poems will be collected during the third test.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 Chinese participants.This study will have two groups,20 subjects will be seperated randomly into one group.

q14.value: The participants will be recuited from universities in Guangzhou. We will not recruit students majored in Chinese Literature as participants .

q15.value: Will post participant sign-up slots by week on the preceding Friday night, with 10 spots posted per week.  We will post 10 new slots each week if, on that Friday night, we are below 40 participants.

question.value:
This study includes 2 factors with 2 levels.

Factor 1: Learning type (Memorization Group vs. Comprehension Group). We will assign participants to different group to finish different daily learning tasks. Memorization Group need to copy the poem ten times everyday through handwriting during the learning process.  Comprehension Group need to complete a hand-written report about the poem including the phonetic infromation, transcription to modern Chinsese as well as some personal reflections.

Factor 2: Material type (Learnt vs. unlearnt). Twenty-four ancient poems were selected from the Book of Songs. Half of them will be chose to be learning materials, the other will be left unlearnt as controls. 

Factor 3: session (pre- and post-learning)

Measured fMRI Variables:
       Experimental blocks: Blocks that present videos about poems, which will be/have been LEARNT during the program.
       Control blocks: Blocks that present videos about poems, which will NOT be learnt during the program.
       Block effect: A voxel shows a block effect if there is statistically greater activity for experimental blocks versus control blocks.
       Learning effect: A voxel shows a learning effect if there is statistically greater block effect, post-learning versus pre-learning (i.e., an interaction between control/experimental blocks and pre-/post-learning).

Measured Behavioral Variables:
       Chinese ancient poem learning performance. It will be collected at the end the learning program by a final paper-pencil test. The test will examine the recognition and comprehension part of the learn poems.

Covariate measures (specific measure, scale/range of measure, which subscale/component of measure you will use):
       Self-report effort made during the learning process. A follow-up survey will be collected after the whole learning program, investigating on average study time each day and their interests on the program.Previous Chinese ancient poem knowledge level score. It will be measured by a test with 100 single choice questions about Chinese ancient poems. 

How was behavioral task performance measured (if task fMRI; e.g., response time, accuracy)?
       Performance accuracy for font-size change detection task during poem videos viewing will be calculated.

We will do a comparison beween Memorization Group and Compresion Group on the Learning effect. Learning effect is defined as a voxel which shows a learning effect if there is statistically greater block effect, post-learning versus pre-learning (i.e., an interaction between control/experimental blocks and pre-/post-learning).

q20.value:
Data pre-processing includes
slice timing correction, motion correction, normalization, and smoothing.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<0.05 or p<0.01 criteria and the cluster correction for determining if the ANOVA suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
If a participant has head motion larger than the size of a voxel, he/she will be excluded. 
If a participant fails to complete the whole learning program which lasts 15-days, he/she will be excluded.

registration_responses.q1: Brain changes after learning to memorize and comprehend poems
registration_responses.q3: In this study, we will examine the brain changes after a 15-days self-learning program to memorize and comprehend ancient Chinese poems measured by functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI). Brain activity will be collected during listening to poem recitation and viewing concurrent subtitle presentation before and after their learning programs. Participants will be arbitrarily assigned to one version of learning protocol, aiming for either recognition or comprehension. The main purpose of this study is to 1) identify brain regions and functional networks recruited in the recognition and comprehension of ancient Chinese poems, 2) explore how the activation of literacy-related areas (such as VWFA and PT) changes after ancient Chinese poem learning, 3) investigate how learning-induced brain changes are associated with behavioral performance.
registration_responses.q4:
Aim 1: Identify brain regions recruited in the recognition and comprehension of ancient Chinese poems.
Brain activity collected using Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) during viewing poem recitation videos before and after leaning will be used to identify brain regions and functional networks recruited in the recognition and comprehension of the poems. The identification process follows from postulates: With the same audiovisual sensory inputs, extensive brain regions and functional networks related to cognitive processing such as attention, long-term memory and language, will be recruited after learning to recognize or comprehend poems. Besides, we predict multimodal sensory integration and sensory-motor interaction will be present after learning for recognition, while frontal-temporal activity involving deeper-level semantic processing will be present after learning for comprehension.

Aim 2: Explore how the activation of literacy-related areas (such as VWFA and PT) changes after ancient Chinese poem learning.
We predict that the activity in literacy-related areas, such as Visual Word Form Area (VWFA) and Planum Temporale (PT), will be modulated by learning experience and learning protocols. 

Aim 3: Investigate how learning-induced brain changes are related to behavioral performance.
If the brain regions and functional networks identified in the efforts aiming towards Aim 1 and 2 are critical for the poem learning, the brain activity changes will be associated with behavioral performance in the final exam after the learning program.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

-The materials of fMRI experiment will be randomly selected from ShiJing(24 ancient poems). Each poem will be seperated into 3 parts and made into videos.
-Every video has been changed one Chinese word’s size and we randomly choose thirty-six of these changed videos and thirty-six unchanged videos as the materials of main experiments in a random order.
